div.l: Reuell and trouþe as Inne a lowe degree
Þey beon ful wroþᵉ / al day as men may see
Þis Ioly prentyse wᵗith his mastre a boode
Til he were nyhe owte of his prentyse hode
Al were he snybbed booþe Eorly ⁊and late
And som tyme ledde wᵗith reuell to Newgate
But at þe laste his maistre him be þyovteyovteþovte
Vppon a daye whanne he his papre sowght
Vppon a proverbe þᵗat seyeþe þᵉ same worde
Wel better is a Roton appul owte of horde
Þanne þᵗat hit Roote al þe Remnaunt
So farithe it / by a Ryotous sarvaunt
Hit is wele lesse harome / to lete passe
Þanne he sheond alle þe sarvauntes in þe place
Þer fore his maistre / gaff him anaqvitaunce
And bad him goo wᵗith sorowe ⁊and mischaunce
And þus þis Iolye / apprentyse hadde his leve
Nowe lette hym Reuell al þᵉ nyght or leve
And for þ̉er is noo theoff wᵗith outen Resseyte
Þat helpithe him to waste and to beyte
Of þᵗat he brybe canne or borowe maye
Anoon he sent his bedde and his arraye
Vn to a Compier of his owne sorte
Þat loued þe deesse / suche Revel ⁊and disporte
And had a wyff þat held for covntenaunce
A shoppe / and swyued for her sustenaunce

¶Off þis tale / chauucier made namore;
¶Nowe this eondith here þe cookestale and nexste

Folowyng begynneþe þe prologe of þᵉ man of
lawes tale ·
Ovre hooste saughe weele þanne / by þᵉ bryght sonne
Þe arke of þe artificiall day haþe þoo eronne
Þe foorþer parte and halfe an houre ⁊and moore
And þoughe he nere not al deepe leorned in loore
He wiste þer by it was þeghee neþe day
Of Aueryll þe messagere to May
And sawhe wele eke þe shadowe of eủreye tree
Was as in lengethe þe same quantitee
As was þe body erecte that causithe hit
And ther for by the shadowe / he took his witte
Þat Phebus wiche shone so clere ⁊and so bright
Degrees was fourty and fyve clomben on hight
And for þᵗat day loo as in latitude
Hit was ten of þe clokke / he gane conclude
Al sodeynlye / he plyght his hors aboute
Lordynges quod he / I warne yow al þⁱˢ rowte
Þe foorþe partye of þis day is nowe goon
Nowe for þe love / of god / and of Saint Iohn
Loosythe noo tyme als forforthe as yᵉ may
Lordyngꝭes þe tyme / it wastithe night ⁊and day
And steelithe from vs / what In oure slepynge
And what thorurghe necligence / in our͗e wakynge
As dooþe þe streeme þᵗat tournith neủre agayne
Descendyng from þe mountayn in to þᵉ playn
Welle canne Senecke / and many Philosophre
Bewayle tymis loste / mor thanne golde in coffre
For losse of cataille maye weele Recouerd be
But losse of tyme / ay sheendith vs quod he
Hit wolle nowte come agayne / wᵗithouten drede
Namore þanne wolle beebee Malkynis mayden hede
Whanne shee hathe loste it in hir wantounisse
Late vs nought mowlen þus in ydelnesse
Sir man of lawe quod he so haue yee blysse
Telle vs a tale anoon / as Forwarde is
Yee been submitted / thorurghe youre free assent

Byheste is dette / and I wolle hold hit fayne
Al my biheste I canne no bett̉re sayn
For suche lawe as man yeeþe anoþ̉er wyte /
He should him self vsen it by Al Ryght
Thus wolle oure texte / but naþee les certayne
I can Right nowe noo thryfty tale yow sayen
Þat Chauucere þaughee he can but lewdelye
Of meetris or of Rimes crafftlye
Naþe seyde hem in suche englysse as he canne
Of olde tymes / as knoweþe many a man
And þowhe he naþe not seyde hem my leve broþ̉er
In on booke he haþe saide hem in a noþ̉er
For he hathe tolde of lovers vppe ⁊and downe
Moo þanne Ovyde made oủer mencioune
In hees epystoles þat ben knowe ful olde
What should I telle him ofte sithe they been told
In yowþe he made of Ceys and Alchion
And siþe hathe he spoken of eueriche oon
Þes noble wyves and þees lovers eke
Who so that wol / hes noble volumes seeke
Cleped the sayntꝭes legende / of Cupide
Þer may he see þe large woundes wyde
Of lucresse / and of Babylon þeesbee
Þhe swerde of Dido for þe false Enee
Þe trowthe of Phillyse for hir Demophon
The playnt of Dianire / and of Ermoon
Of Adriane / and of ysaphillioo
Þe barayne yle stondyng in the See
Þe dreynte lawrer for his sawe awo
Þe theeres of Eleyne / and eke hir grete woo
Booþe of Cressyde / and of landomea
Þe creweltee of þe qwene Medea
Þe litelle chylderin honging by þᵉ hals
For þee Iason þat waste of love so fals
O parmistra Penolopee / and Alceste
Yowre wyfhode he comendithe wᵗith þᵉ beste
But certainlye no wondre writeþᵉ hee
Of þat wicked ensaumple / of Canace
Wiche loved hir owne broth̉er so synffullye
